_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

Commitment to the Community

BASF Corporation has a long tradition of operating its facilities in the safest possible manner. BASF also
believes In being a responsible corporate citizen and maintaining open, constructive dialogue with our
neighbors. These principles are an integral part of our corporate vision statement and values. We believe that sharing this information with our neighbors makes good sense. By doing so, we believe the community will better understand how safe and ecologically sound BASF operations are.

Policies

BASF Corporation has the following Corporate Guidelines related to environmental, health and safety:
We produce products that are safe to manufacture, use and dispose of. We assist our customers to use our products safely and in an environmentally sound manner. We provide them with information on correct handling of our products. We minimize the impact on mankind and the environment during production, storage, transportation, marketing and use of our products. Economic considerations do not take priority over
environmental protection, health and safety. An important contribution to" Sustainable Development" is our involvement in the "Responsible Care" initiative worldwide. This applies to our products and services in all our businesses and affiliates. We are committed to making continuous improvements in safety, health and environmental protection. We do this acting on our own initiative and in consultation with recognized regulatory authorities. We take any action judged to be necessary, whether or not dictated by statutory obligation or official regulations. We encourage safety, environmental and health awareness among employees. We regard it as an important corporate duty to advance science and technology in order to improve safety and
environmental protection. We carefully weigh the potential benefits and risks of new discoveries and technologies in dialogue with scientists and society before dec

iding on how to proceed. We pursue an open dialogue with all relevant opinion leaders in society. Our goals are to promote and strengthen mutual understanding and deepen trust in what we do. The BASF Corporation Beaumont Site implements these policies through site-specific programs and procedures.


The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the BASF Beaumont Site

Accidental Release Prevention Program
To prevent accidental releases, this facility fully complies with the EPA Risk Management Program and the OSHA Process Safety Management standard. Extensive efforts have been made to avoid situations that could provide the conditions which could lead to the release of any chemical used on site. The efforts include (1) HAZOP or Zurich analysis of all new or modified systems, (2) Pre-startup safety reviews, and (3) Specific operating procedures for normal conditions as well emergency situations.

It is the policy of this site to train employees to respond to emergencies including fire and chemical spill. The site maintains an Emergency Response Team trained as per the applicable standards. This Team drills periodically to maintain effectiveness and be ready if a accident should occur.
The stationary source and regulated substances handled
Facility Description

The BASF Corporation Beaumont Site produces several brands of trade name herbicides. These include:
Banvel(R), Clarity(R), Distinct(R) and Frontier(R), as well as a variety of other formulations, which are used in the farm sector to enhance growth, to eliminate weeds, and to improve the yield in general Chlorine, dimethylamine, methyl chloride, and formaldehyde are used to produce some of these products. 
Worst Case
Toxic gas release of chlorine with off-site impacts resulting from the rupture of a chlorine railcar. Vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of dimethylamine from a railcar with off-site impacts.
Alternative
Vessel leak of chlorine with minimal off-site impact. Activ

e mitigation that is available but not accounted for in determining the off-site impact includes firewater sprays to limit gas evolution as well as a flow-limiting valve, Vessel leak of methyl chloride with no off-site impact. Passive mitigation considered is a dike and active mitigation includes a foam sprinkler system. Vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of dimethylamine with minimal off-site impact. Active mitigation consists of diluting anhydrous dimethylamine with water upon receiving it, which drastically reduces its flammability.
A vessel leak of formaldehyde with minimal off-site impact Passive mitigation considered is a dike, drains and a sump. Active mitigation consists of a water curtain and fire watered foam monitors. 


The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
To prevent accidental releases, this facility fully complies with the EPA Risk Management Program and the OSHA Process Safety Management standard. The facility purchases equipment that meets requirements for the intended service as specified by BASF engineering standards.  The Site inspects, and maintains equipment and piping as recommended by the codes applicable for that equipment and service. All BASF engineering standards are based on Recognized And Generally Accepted Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP). All changes to the process are thoroughly evaluated before implementation. This is our first and most effective prevention program against chemical leaks within the site. 

The site also maintains remote sensors for chlorine at the railcar unload area that alarm in the control room to alert the staff if a release is detected. Remote sensors for flammability are provided in the unload areas and tank farms that alarm in the control room to alert the staff if a leak is detected. 

Additionally, the operations employees regularly walk through the process areas to look for leaks of any chemicals.


Five Year Accident History
This facility has

not had an accident within the last five years that met the definition of a RMP accident.


Emergency Response Program
This facility has an emergency response plan that is coordinated with the local emergency planning commission. The site is a member of the Sabine Neches Area Chiefs Association. which is a mutual aid group and assists the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Commission. The site maintains a complete fire fighting facility manned by volunteer employees who receive extensive training. This training consists of offsite training as well as regularly scheduled on-site drills. There is a plant wide system of fire water piping with pumps and power. A system of foam generators is available wherever flammable solvents are stored and throughout the tank farm.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The policy of the BASF corporation is to always seek ways to improve the safety of our facilities. We do this through soliciting ideas from all employees and contractors, accident investigations, and hazard reviews. Any action items from these sources are recorded into a database and tracked to completion.
